Author: nerosalt
Content:
The Rhodesian Fireforce is one of if not the most effective counterinsurgency tactics ever executed. 
Please excuse my RSF fanboying.
In short, the fireforce was a rapid-response air assault tactic, usually consisting of 3 or more gunships, responsible for carrying the 4-man sticks who are to be deployed on the ground and supporting machinegun fire, a command car, housing the commander, who will scout the area for insurgents and provide suppressing fire, and a transport plane to paradrop the before mentioned sticks, although sometimes fireforces lacked a transport plane and instead uses additional G-ships. 
Addtionally, the airships are supported by a light attack aircraft, sometimes also supported by CAS, light bombers or fighter bombers.
Fireforce heavily relied on the accuracy of the reported insurgent sightings. The fireforce could be called in by observation posts (mostly constructed by insurgent-turned RSF forces from the Selous Scouts or other branches.) or patrols, the fireforce was also dispatched in response to insurgent attacks.
The execution itself consisted of the command ship entering and verifying the targets, opening fire and sending down the G-Ships to either cut off the insurgents as they fled or to drop on the ground and form a sweepline. After the targets have been verified, paratroopers would be dropped from the transport aircraft and sweep the ground.
On the ground, the sweeplines consisted of the four man sticks, they would usually alternate fire, two covering as the two pushed forwards.
All of this resulted in a kill ratio of 1:60, sometimes 1:80. 
Fireforce was, by its core, creating 10 clones of yourself and casting fireball. Overwhelming your enemy with immense firepower, making sure none survive.

Author: nerosalt
Content: Fireforce was not the most effective counterinsurgency tactic, it is far from it.

Author: nerosalt
Content: It clearly racked up a lot of kills, maybe even one of the most, but it is far from perfect and inherently flawed.

Author: nerosalt
Content: To put it simply, fireforce was expensive to handle and expensive to maintain.

Author: nerosalt
Content: Before we get to the obvious, fireforce required a intelligence network that frankly, Rhodesia could not effectively maintain in the long term. It required massive amounts of intelligence gathering as a single operation was immensely costly and fireforces were usually assigned to large areas.

Author: nerosalt
Content: And most obviously, it was EXPENSIVE.

Author: nerosalt
Content: By expensive I mean EXPENSIVE.

Author: nerosalt
Content: Multiple aircrafts and hundreds of rounds per operation, not to mention the multiple dozen soldiers required. Once more, not to mention the immense amount of training required to sufficiently train the gunners, paratroopers, pilots, etc.

Author: nerosalt
Content:
For a rich country like the US, this may be effective, a similar tactic was used by the US during the Vietnam War. Annihilating Vietcong elements and driving them back massively. But even for the US, they too sustained massive losses numbering in the hundreds. 
Now imagine a suffering country, sanctioned and embargoed, a 1:20 RSF to ZANLA/ZIPRA ratio.

Author: nerosalt
Content: Now many people argue that fireforce isn't a effective tactic due to it only working against lightly armed and disorganised forces.

Author: nerosalt
Content: I disagree on this point, while yes, the effectiveness would decrease, but if done successfully, it would still net positive outcomes 70% of the time.

Author: nerosalt
Content: The other 30%, you're looking at losing a few helicopters.

Author: nerosalt
Content: In my opinion, fireforce's biggest flaw is that it just isn't a good COIN tactic.

Author: nerosalt
Content: By that I mean, it isn't effective in countering insurgency.

Author: nerosalt
Content: Fireforce was an tactic that was purposefully made to maximise casualties in the fastest time possible, as I said before, it was expensive.

Author: nerosalt
Content: The thing is, fireforce itself could not isolate and annihilate enemy forces.

Author: nerosalt
Content: Counterinsurgency requires not only the annihilation of insurgent forces, but the control over entry and exit points, this cannot be done with fireforce.

Author: nerosalt
Content: As stated before, the US army used a tactic similar to fireforce only with the support of additional infantry elements to form a *kessel* and destroy the enemy.

Author: nerosalt
Content: Even then, they sustained considerable losses.

Author: nerosalt
Content: Rhodesia, on the other hand, physically could not allocate additional forces.

Author: nerosalt
Content: There is no cauldron, there is no nothing.

Author: nerosalt
Content: Fireforce is too expensive of a tactic when you can use much cheaper and sustainable tactics that net the same.
